awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: RUI: Towards Resolving the Dynamic Optimality Conjecture.
awd_abstract_narration:
Searching is a fundamental problem in computer science, and faster search algorithms have been the focus of many researchers for decades. Being a basic primitive in all databases, fast searching in the age of big data has numerous applications in almost any field of data science. A binary search tree (BST) was one of the first and simplest data structures developed for searching, in which the keys in the database are stored in a binary tree, which allows an easy search algorithm to locate keys. In the real world, a sequence of searches come in an online fashion (the next search is revealed only after the current search is conducted), which led researchers to ask whether dynamically adjusting a BST may help access future (unknown) searches faster. While it may seem counterintuitive, for a wide variety of special search sequences, there exist online data structures that perform these searches almost as fast as the best offline algorithm -- one that knew all the searches in advance. Two such data structures are Splay Trees, developed by Sleator and Tarjan [1985] , and Greedy developed by Lucas [1988] and Munro [2000]. The dynamic optimality conjecture states that one of these online algorithms, in fact, accesses all sequences almost as fast as the optimal offline algorithm. This conjecture, widely regarded as one of fundamental problems in data structures, remains unresolved after 35 years. In this project the PI proposes three avenues to attack this conjecture.  This project aims at producing the next generation of researchers and promoting under-represented groups in science and technology. Because of the simplicity of the conjecture, many undergraduate students will be able to understand it, appreciate the field of data structures, and thereby be motivated to pursue a career in computer science. The PI already has minority undergraduate and graduate students involved in this project. CUNY Queens College is a Hispanic-serving institution. The PI is committed to engaging more undergraduate students and women in research.

The dynamic optimality conjecture is perhaps one of the most elusive unsolved problems in data structures. It postulates the existence of an online binary search tree (BST) which is O(1) competitive with the optimal offline self-balancing BST (called OPT). It is one of the simplest cases of instance optimality, and has been particularly elusive in that highly restricted consequences of the conjecture had remained open for three decades. The traversal conjecture and the weighted dynamic finger property are two recently settled conjectures (the former being resolved by the PI and his co-authors). After overcoming these last-remaining barriers, one needs a new set of barriers that will get us closer to proving or disproving dynamic optimality for the two main candidates, Splay trees and Greedy. The PI maps out a plan to attack this conjecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit: This award resulted in 11 peer-reviewed articles published in top conferences and journals, and 2 preprints under submission. In a series of articles published in Innovations in Theoretical Computer Science (ITCS 2024) and the International Conference on Approximation Algorithms for Combinatorial Optimization Problems (APPROX 2024) the PI established a unified framework for instance optimality for static problems. This framework applies to most existing works on instance optimality. Using this framework, the PI was able to make progress on 25 year old open problems stated in influential works. In particular, the PI developed almost instance optimal algorithms for the problems of bichromatic and bipartite sorting, that are natural generalizations of the fundamental problem of sorting. In another work published in Latin American Symposium on Informatics (LATIN 2021) the PI studied sorting and searching in the priced-information setting in the external memory model.

The award also resulted in 3 articles on a new style of optimization, where instead of finding one optimal solution, the user wants to obtain a diverse set of almost optimal solutions. This style of optimization has several applications ranging from boosting security by switching between the diverse solutions to energy efficiency and giving the user more choice.

The award also resulted in 5 top-tier publications  in the field of Machine Learning (ICLR 2023, UAI 2022, NeurIPS 2021, ICLR 2021, Front. of Computer Science 2024). Several of these works (e.g. the feature-dependent noise model in ICLR 2021) also exhibit an instance-dependent analysis, similar to the question of the dynamic optimality conjecture.


Mentoring: PI Goswami mentored 3 PhD students during the course of this project. PI Goswami also supervised two Undergraduate students who worked on projects related to tasks in the proposal, and implemented the two main candidate algorithms for the dynamic optimality conjecture. The students not only gained first-hand experience conducting research in computer science, but also collaborated with each other and with the PI's colleagues in various universities. 


Undergraduate Education Impact: The PI has incorporated the topics of Splay trees, Greedy, and the dynamic optimality conjecture into the curriculum for an undergraduate course called "algorithms for big data". Binary search trees are one of the first data structures taught in an algorithms course, and the students find the content easy to understand and also easy to implement. The PI has introduced a new seminar course at Queens College, where researchers from the NYC area present their latest research. However, this differs from the usual colloquium in the sense that a) undergraduate students introduce the speaker and some of the speaker's works before the talk, and b) two undergraduate students give presentations on the speaker's works a week after the seminar. This course received extremely favorable reviews from students, who not only got a glimpse of the latest research in several fields of computer science, but were also able to personally interact with established researchers. 

The PI traveled to the United Kingdom, Mexico and Poland to disseminate the results achieved, during this award. 

This award was used to fund salaries for graduate students, summer salary for the PI, and travel by the students and the PI.
